newsitem.title: USA: US Northeast spot power holds steady on cold snap.
newsitem.headline: US Northeast spot power holds steady on cold snap.

text.p: Spot bulk electricity prices in the northeastern U.S. held mostly steady Thursday versus Wednesday's level as a cold snap continued its grip on the region.
This week's price rise was capped by forecasts calling for temperatures to moderate from recent lows by early next week.
"It looks like there's a warming trend next week," said one New York trader.
Nevertheless, scattered snowfall and frigid weather were anticipated to continue for the next several days.
For Friday, the Northeast's temperatures were predicted to peak in the 20s-30s Fahrenheit and to bottom in single digits to the teens. Snowfall in western New York was expected to end late today.

In the western part of the New York Power Pool (NYPP) district, peak, non-firm electricity for Friday delivery was quoted at $23.00-$25.00 a megawatt hour (MWh), compared with Wednesday's quote near $25.00 for Thursday delivery.
Western NYPP power for non-firm delivery during light load hours on Friday was again assessed near $15.00.
In the eastern part of NYPP, peak, non-firm electricity for Friday was valued at $31.00-$32.00, a tighter range than Wednesday's $30.00-$32.00 for Thursday.
Off-peak, non-firm Friday electricity in eastern NYPP was assessed at $17.00-$18.50, lower than Wednesday's range of $18.00-$20.00.
In the New England Power Pool (NEPOOL), peak, non-firm electricity for Friday at the Northeast Utilities border was valued at $36.00-$37.00, down from $38.00-$39.00 on Wednesday.
Non-firm, off-peak NEPOOL power for next-day delivery to the NU border remained in the $20.00-$21.00 range.
